longDescription:
The Blood of Isis, Amulet of Protection and Resurrection The Tyet, also known as the Knot of Isis or the Blood of Isis, is an ancient Egyptian
                    amulet closely associated with the goddess Isis and her powers of protection, healing,
                    and resurrection. Resembling the ankh but with its arms folded down, the tyet was one
                    of the most important funerary amulets in ancient Egypt.
name: Tyet (Knot of Isis)
materials: Red jasper, carnelian, or red glass
shortDescription: The Blood of Isis, Amulet of Protection and Resurrection

extendedContent.content:
The Tyet, also known as the Knot of Isis or the Blood of Isis, is an ancient Egyptian
                    amulet closely associated with the goddess Isis and her powers of protection, healing,
                    and resurrection. Resembling the ankh but with its arms folded down, the tyet was one
                    of the most important funerary amulets in ancient Egypt.
                
                
                    The amulet was traditionally made from red materials - jasper, carnelian, or red glass -
                    representing the magical blood of Isis. It was placed on the throat or chest of mummies
                    to invoke the protection of Isis in the journey through the underworld.
extendedContent.title: Description and Appearance

extendedContent.content:
Chapter 156 of the Book of the Dead specifically concerns the tyet amulet, providing
                    instructions for its preparation and the spell to be recited:
                
                
                    "You have your blood, Isis. You have your power, Isis. You have your magic, Isis.
                    The amulet is a protection for this Great One; it will drive away whoever would
                    commit a crime against him."
                
                
                    The text specifies that the amulet should be made of red jasper and placed on the
                    deceased's neck, ensuring that the person would have the protection of Isis's blood
                    and magical power throughout their journey through the Duat (underworld).
extendedContent.title: The Book of the Dead
Related Articles
extendedContent.content: Related Articles The Ankh Book of Thoth Emerald Tablet

description: The Blood of Isis, Amulet of Protection and Resurrection
significance: Symbolic Meanings: Blood of Isis: The life force and magical power of the goddess Protection: Guarding the deceased in the afterlife Resurrection: Isis's power to restore life (as she did for Osiris) Feminine Power: Connection to the womb and motherhood Binding Magic: The knot that binds and protects
bibliography: Andrews, Carol. Amulets of Ancient Egypt . British Museum Press, 1994.
Faulkner, R.O., trans. The Ancient Egyptian Book of the Dead . British Museum Press, 1985.
Pinch, Geraldine. Magic in Ancient Egypt . British Museum Press, 1994.
